fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-16167].
  {panel}

The Confluence logfile configuration don't switch automatically after startup, even with the distributed log4j.properties. This is what happens
* after Startup, the /admin/viewlog4j.action Page shows in the table Existing Levels just two entries: org.apache.catalina.cluster and {root}}, both at INFO-level.
* after pressing [Production], the table is filled with loggers listed in the properties file. This configuration is used and may be changed (e.g in Level), also.

Turning log4j debugging reveals that:
* log4j will first try to lookup log4j.xml in the classpath. If this fail, it will lookup for log4j.properties
* Tomcat5.5 has it's own classloader branch for the Catalina engine, from that the application can't "see" this log4 configuration (usually at ../user/share/tomcat-5.5/server/lib/classes/)
* Tomcat6 uses a new (unified) classloader 
*  If one will declare the Tomcat logging configuration in XML and an Application uses the old property syntax, the wrong one will be choosen ("preferred").

This log4j documentation explains why this happens and suggests ways (eg JNDI {{comp/env}} lookups) to resolve: [Supporting the log4j RepositorySelector in Servlet Containers |http://www.qos.ch/logging/sc.jsp]



Regards,
Edoardo

Avni

Allow a user to update their status OR user stream via RSS. Let a user add an RSS feed to their profile. This then updates their status and/or user stream. 

Eg "Sherif blogged xyz" <<LINK>> 

This would allow the status update and user stream to become more "FriendFeed" like.

In our organisation we have 50+ of users that have their own internal corporate blogs. We also have an internal blogging platform (Wordpress MU) for users to publish blogs.

Having this feature would mean a user could "link" their blog posts with their Confluence user stream. This would open up confluence to be an aggregator of other internal collaboration tools within the enterprise. It would also mean a user can use the confluence user profile/user stream capability without necessary having to publish blogs/article within confluence, but can do it through an external system.

h3. Problem

Discovered during user sessions... "The Add Table dialog is hard and slow for me to use."

- When entering letters into the row and column fields and clicking "OK", blank space is inserted into the editor. An error message would be more useful.
- Some users would find it faster and easier if they could select a number rather than type it in.
- "First Row is Heading" label is grammatically incorrect and too long.

h3. Solution

Using the new lightbox style (e.g. macro browser), implement something like this:

!insert_table.png|thumbnail!

This will align the dialog with the current direction and make it less confusing for the confused users.

If someone wants to do something _FANTASTIC_ for _FUN_, Microsoft Word 2004 has a pretty good implementation for inserting dialogs. But it's probably a time consuming implementation and one not worth the time (which is why I haven't proposed it as the primary solution).
fields.summary: Improve "Insert Table" dialog

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-15991].
  {panel}

I've customised ConfluenceActionSupport.properties to replace the confluence expressions with terms that I expect to be more familiar to my target audience, who are very non-geek.  I suspect this is not an uncommon activity.

It was actually a bit tricky, because I couldn't just search and replace, because the terms I wanted to change are used in different ways, only some of which I wanted to change.

For example, sometimes Confluence is used to mean "this website", and sometimes it is used to mean "the software".

Where it was used to mean the website, I've tried to change it.  Where it is used to mean the software, I've tried not to change it.

"Page" also has multiple meanings.  Sometimes it means any confluence page, including blogposts.  Sometimes it means a confluence page, excluding blogposts.  Sometimes it means any web page, confluence or not.

And of course, I had to be careful only to change to the right of each "=" sign.

It would have been much easier to make the changes I wanted if, at the top of ConfluenceActionSupport.properties, there had been a block that said 

confluence_software=Confluence
confluence_site=Confluence
confluence_space=space
confluence_regular_page=page
confluence_any_page=page
confluence_blogpost=blogpost
confluence_dashboard=...

And them, if references to page were qualified as ${confluence_regular_page}, or some such.

It would mean that I would only have to make the changes I want in a few places, and better still, it would mean that I wouldn't have to work out which ones to change and which ones to leave.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-15892].
  {panel}

A large amount of work has been done updating documentation for bundled macros in Confluence 3.0. This raises the problem that the bundled macro notation help will be less polished or even inaccurate.

This issue includes the use of aliases in the Macro Browser, where a macro opened with one name (e.g. 'nl') will be saved as another ('nolink'), or where an old "uber" macro name like 'viewfile' is directed to a more specific macro like 'viewdoc'.

As the Macro Browser links directly to the CAC docs it makes sense for CAC to be the "source of truth" and for the notation guide to follow. We need to find a way to do this without merely replicating the CAC text (and its i18ns).

In the short term, we could simply point users to the Macro Browser or CAC for problem notation guide entries.

  {panel}

The APIs for moving a page currently conflate these three activities, I suspect because that's the way it's done in the user interface:

* Moving a page to a new space
* Moving a page to a new parent
* Moving a page to a different order within the same parent

This makes the APIs (and implementations) really complicated and is the source of a bunch of bugs. It would be much better if the API treated these things as three separate operations that could then be composed.

Some care would have to be taken: for example if you move a page to a new space then change its parent, you shouldn't have to rebuild the ancestor table more than once. Still, that's eminently doable.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-15831].
  {panel}

If an attachment has many versions (in the tens thousands range), it can cause Confluence to crash with an OOM when viewing the view attachments page. This is because the view attachments page renders a list of all attachments on a page as well as all its versions (its versions are just added a class hidden and the arrow to display them just toggles this class).

We should either load the previous version only when the user clicks on the arrow by an AJAX call, or even provide a paginated view of such a large number of versions. 

If if the attachment does not have version in the tens of thousands, but does have a significant amount, it will cause the attachments page rendering time to degrade badly. 

Thus this solution should not only consider prevent the OOME but also keeping the page load time scalable.
